title: 105_s1311
content: The Act titled "Iran Missile Proliferation Sanctions Act of 1997" requires reports on missile proliferation to Iran. The President must submit reports to the House and Senate committees identifying foreign persons involved in transferring goods or technology to Iran for ballistic missiles, within 30 days of the Act's enactment in 1997. The Act requires reports to be submitted within specific timeframes, with exceptions for persons previously identified or sanctioned. Section 4 does not need to be identified in subsequent reports due to the same transfer, transaction, or attempt. Section 3 imposes sanctions. Sanctions must be imposed on foreign persons identified in reports under subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of section 2, effective 30 days after the report triggering the sanction is submitted. Sanctions must be imposed on foreign persons identified in reports under subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of section 2, effective 30 days after the report triggering the sanction is submitted. The sanctions include an arms export sanction lasting for a minimum of 2 years, prohibiting the sale of items on the United States Munitions List. Sanctions must be imposed on foreign persons identified in reports under subsections (a)(1) and (a)(2) of section 2, effective 30 days after the report triggering the sanction is submitted. This includes prohibiting the sale of items on the United States Munitions List, dual-use goods, and technology on the control list, as well as withholding United States assistance for a minimum of 2 years. The President has the authority to waive sanctions on foreign persons if convinced they did not contribute to Iran's ballistic missile program after August 8, 1995. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL INFORMATION REGARDING ACTIONS BY GOVERNMENT OF PRIMARY JURISDICTION. The President must provide information on individuals in the report, including whether the government of primary jurisdiction was aware of their activities. If not, reasons for not informing that government should be explained. If the government was aware, efforts made should be described. The report must include details on the individual's activities, the government's efforts to prevent those activities, and an assessment of the effectiveness of those efforts. If the government failed to prevent the activities, any sanctions imposed by the United States Government should be described. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. This section defines "government of primary jurisdiction" as the government under whose laws a foreign person is organized or headquartered, and "foreign person" as any entity organized outside the United States.
